summary: This is a letter motion from the U.S. Attorney's Office to Judge Alison J. Nathan in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, arguing that the birth certificates of the minor victims are self-authenticating under Federal Rules of Evidence and should be admitted without requiring testimony from records custodians. The government seeks to avoid calling witnesses from five state agencies.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced in the document title (United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell).

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the Ghislaine Maxwell case to whom this letter motion is addressed.

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted this letter motion.

events.title: Government Motion on Birth Certificate Authentication
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office files a motion requesting the court to rule that the birth certificates of minor victims in the Ghislaine Maxwell case are self-authenticating documents under Federal Rule of Evidence 902.

locations: 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services
Town of North Hempstead, Nassau County, New York
keyFacts: The government has obtained certified birth certificates for multiple minor victims in the Ghislaine Maxwell case (Exhibits GX-11 through GX-16).
The defense has refused to stipulate to the authenticity of these birth certificates despite having no reason to doubt their authenticity.
The government argues the birth certificates are self-authenticating under Federal Rule of Evidence 902(4) as certified copies of public records with proper seals and signatures.
The motion seeks to avoid calling records custodians from five different state agencies to testify about the birth certificates.
The document references that certain victims and witnesses are testifying under pseudonyms, and privacy protections are being maintained.
